SENT.plain: Thirty-one patients with a columnar lined oesophagus were studied
Half the patients were aged 70 years or over and only four patients were under 60 years of age at presentation
More than two-thirds of patients presented with a complication

Comparison by age showed a significant difference (P = 0.006) between the nine patients with uncomplicated Barrett's oesophagus (median age 64 years, range 28-79 years) and the 22 presenting with a complication (median age 75 years, range 36-89 years)
This finding supports the view that the condition is acquired and that complications occur after injury resulting from prolonged reflux
Of the remaining 26 patients only seven (27%) underwent an antireflux procedure
Old age, associated medical problems and the effective control of symptoms by medical management (drugs and dilatation), reduced the need for surgery in this elderly population
